ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS COPYRIGHT ACT

(Amendments in relation to parallel importation of goods)


    1. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Law if he will propose amendments to the Copyright Act in relation to parallel importation of goods.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Law): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the Chief Justice's decision in PP v Teoh Ai Nee and Ngoh Chin Heng was first reported in the press, a committee was formed to study its implications and to review the law and policy on parallel imports of copyright products. The committee will complete its review and make its recommendations soon.

    The decision of the Chief Justice highlighted some unintended effects of the law. When Parliament enacted the Copyright Bill in 1987, the House was told that the legislative intent was not to prohibit parallel imports, only counterfeit products.

    The decision turned on the technical interpretation of a particular section of the Copyright Act, which was open to alternative interpretations. At the same time, however, the Chief Justice made it clear that formulating Singapore's policy on parallel imports should be the task of the legislature and not that of the judiciary.

    Government's policy on parallel imports has not changed. We must strike a balance between, on the one hand, ensuring cheaper prices for consumers and, on the other, providing sufficient protection to the copyright industries, to enable them to reap the benefits of their efforts and so have the incentive to develop the business. Once we receive the committee's report, we will propose amendments to the law to clarify this.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Tampines GRC): Sir, due to the uncertainty, when will this committee complete its report?

Column: 357



     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, the committee's report will be made available to Government some time in early March, and within two months the Government will clarify the position.

SALE OF HAWKER STALLS
(Withdrawal of privilege and priority to sitting tenants who profiteer from GST)


    2. Mr Koo Tsai Kee asked the Minister for the Environment if he will consider the recommendation of the Consumers' Association of Singapore to withdraw the privilege and priority of sitting tenants to purchase their hawker stalls if they profiteer from the implementation of the Goods and Services Tax.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are some 23,000 stalls in Environment, HDB and JTC hawker centres. Centres operated by the private sector have another 13,000 stalls. These stalls compete with one another and competition keeps prices at an affordable level. Stallholders in Environment, HDB and JTC centres are required to display price tags and sell at the declared prices. Enforcement officers regularly inspect these centres to ensure compliance.

    My Ministry supports the view that centres that profiteer on account of GST or other pretext should be excluded from the Sale of Stalls Scheme. If CASE has established that profiteering takes place in a particular hawker centre, it can refer the matter to my Ministry.

PRICE INCREASES
(Types and quanta implemented by Government departments
and statutory boards before implementation of GST)


    3. Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew asked the Minister for Finance what types and quanta of price increases affecting the public have been implemented by Government departments and statutory boards since the announcement of the Goods and Services Tax in his Budget

Column: 358

Statement in 1993 and why these increases were allowed before the implementation of the GST on 1st April 1994.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, between February 1993, when GST was first announced, and the end of January this year, fee increases were implemented by six Government departments, institutions or statutory boards. These are listed in the Annex (Cols. 439 - 440) already distributed to hon. Members.
Annex - FEE INCREASES BETWEEN FEBRUARY 1993 AND JANUARY 1994 (Cols. 439 - 440)


    Fee increases are necessary when manpower, material or operating costs have risen significantly. The increases introduced since February last year were unrelated to GST.

    Government's policy is to recover unavoidable manpower and material related cost increase through gradual and periodic fee increases in order to minimise their impact on inflation. Delaying such increases will only result in larger and more painful adjustments later on.

     Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew (Nominated Member): With reference to the Annex, would the Minister assure the House that university fees will not be increased again this year since GST will be applied to university fees?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: University fees are outside my portfolio. But I will refer the Member's request to the Minister for Education.

     Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew: Sir, with regard to item No. 6 in the Annex, I think there may be a mistake in the computation because car park charges were raised by about 12 1/2% during the year.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Car park charges cover a range of increases. I do not know which particular one the Member is referring to.

     Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew: It says "... car parks charges were raised by between 7 and 10%".

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Which one is 12%?

Column: 359



     Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew: Actually it is 12 1/2% because the charges were raised from 40 cents to 45 cents and from 80 cents to 90 cents.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: These are the half-hourly and hourly charges. But item 6 probably refers to the season car park charges. The car park charges cover a range of increases. It is possible that one of the increases could be 12 1/2% and therefore what the Member says is true.

ONE-CENT COINS
(Promotion on use)


    4. Mr Koo Tsai Kee asked the Minister for Finance whether he will promote the use of one-cent coins by encouraging the Government to fix charges and fees to the nearest one cent.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no need for Government to fix its fees and charges to the nearest one cent when GST is implemented on 1st April 1994. This is because Government rates will remain unchanged on 1st April 1994, notwithstanding that Government fees and charges will attract GST where similar supplies are or might be made by the private sector. Government's purpose in doing this is to facilitate the implementation of GST.

    Government fees and charges are adjusted periodically to account for increase in costs. When changes become necessary, the increases are fixed by rounding down to the nearest 10 cents for ease of collection.

    To allay public concern about excessive price increases and profiteering, retailers are encouraged to round off their prices to the nearest one cent. The Board of Commissioners of Currency, Singapore (BCCS) will increase the circulation of one-cent coins to meet additional demand.

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, is the Minister aware that one-cent coins are not readily available in the market? When GST is implemented from 1st April onwards, there may be some problems in rounding down or rounding

Column: 360

up to the nearest one-cent. My question to the Minister is: when and where will these one-cent coins be distributed around the island?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The coins will be made available. You cannot physically distribute the coins to people unless they ask for it. They will be available to retailers who feel that there is a need for it.

SHIPYARD ACCIDENTS
(Precautions)


    The following Question stood in the name of Dr Kanwaljit Soin -

    5. To ask the Minister for Labour what further precautions the Government intends to take to reduce loss of life and limb in shipyard accidents.

Column: 360

ENFORCEMENT OF SAFETY REGULATIONS IN SHIPYARDS


    6. Dr Toh Keng Kiat asked the Minister for Labour whether more effective enforcement of safety regulations will be carried out in shipyards in order to prevent further accidents due to explosions and flash fires.

     Dr Toh Keng Kiat (Nominated Member): Sir, on behalf of Dr Soin, Question No. 5. May I have your permission to ask Question No. 6 in my name now?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     The Minister for Labour (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to answer Questions Nos. 5 and 6 together since they cover the same area?

     Mr Speaker: All right.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Sir, the Ministry's approach to safety in shipyards and, for that matter, any other factory or worksite, is to impose and enforce all practicable safety precautions. We systematically review and amend safety regulations, so that workers can work in a safer environment.

    Unfortunately, from time to time, lapses in compliance and human errors have resulted in accidents, sometimes with

Column: 361

fatal consequences. In 1992, there were two major shipyard accidents involving the loss of 14 lives and 75 workers suffering injuries. The Government convened two Committees of Inquiry to look into the causes and circumstances of the accidents. The Committees conducted thorough investigations and hearings. They recommended enhanced safety measures for hot works, chemical usage and audit of safety management system. In May 1993, my Ministry ordered Sembawang Shipyard, where both accidents took place, to comply with all the recommendations. The shipyard had done so, including conducting an external safety audit.

    In addition, the Ministry organised a study mission to Japan to study safety management in Japanese shipyards. Senior management of major shipyards and representatives of the Association of Singapore Marine Industries (ASMI) joined the mission to study first-hand the Japanese safety management system.

    The Ministry organised a Workshop on Accident Prevention in Shipyards in October 1993 to discuss and disseminate the recommendations of the Committees, and the findings of the study mission. Senior managers of shipyards and union representatives took part and agreed to implement these recommendations in their own shipyards.

    Subsequently, the Department of Industrial Safety (DIS) monitored monthly progress in implementing the safety recommendations. The regular monitoring and enforcement visits showed that the major shipyards have implemented practically all the recommendations of the Committees of Inquiry. Shipyards are also in the process of implementing the recommendations of the study mission to Japan.

    The only major recommendation of the Committees of Inquiry which is still not fully implemented is the conduct of safety audits by external auditors with specific experience in auditing safety systems of shipyards. So far, only Sembawang Shipyard had conducted such audit. ASMI is actively sourcing for consultants to

Column: 362

draw up standard auditing procedures, which the other shipyards could use for their external safety audits.

    The Ministry has also conducted a comprehensive review of existing safety provisions for shipyards. The recommendations of the two Committees of Inquiry on measures to prevent fire and explosion have been incorporated in a new set of safety regulations. In addition, the review also covers other hazards, such as those arising from the use of scaffolding, lifting equipment and electrical installations. These regulations will be gazetted shortly.

    Apart from these steps to tighten regulation of safety management, the Department of Industrial Safety conducts regular inspections of shipyards to ensure that they comply with accepted safety practices and procedures. In 1993, the Department of Industrial Safety conducted 1,223 inspections of shipyards. Shipyards which had violated safety regulations were issued with notices of non-compliance or composition fines. For more serious violations, shipyards were prosecuted in court. In instances where the workplace was grossly unsafe, stop work orders were issued to force the shipyard to improve safety measures before work resumed.

    I was therefore deeply saddened by the report of the tragic accident in Jurong Shipyard in the morning of 8th February this year. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to the family of the nine workers who died in the accident and the two injured workers.

    I have appointed a Committee of Inquiry to determine the causes and circumstances leading to the accident and to recommend appropriate preventive measures. Shipyard managements must rigorously implement safety measures and stringently enforce compliance by their workers and employees of their sub-contractors. Workers must also understand that when they are working in hazardous conditions, disregarding safety precautions can be disastrous both to themselves and to fellow workers nearby.

    I hope that the three accidents which occurred so close together will remain a

Column: 363

painful and vivid reminder for a long, long time to all shipyard managements and their workers to work safely.

HDB INTERIM AND MAJOR UPGRADING PROGRAMMES
(Integration)


    7. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Acting Minister for National Development if he will explain how the Housing and Development Board integrates both the interim and major upgrading programmes for flats; and whether a flat, which has undergone interim upgrading, will be entitled to major upgrading later on.

     The Acting Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Interim Upgrading Programme complements the Main Upgrading Programme. The Main Upgrading Programme is intended for flats older than 17 years. The Interim Upgrading Programme allows HDB residents of precincts in the 10 to 17 years age band to enjoy some benefits of the Main Upgrading Programme earlier. Otherwise, they would have to wait for more than eight years before they are eligible for the Main Upgrading Programme. Works under the Interim Upgrading Programme are confined to the precinct and block level.

    Since the Interim Upgrading Programme is merely an advancement of some of the improvements under the Main Upgrading Programme, precincts that are upgraded under the Interim Upgrading Programme are still eligible for the Main Upgrading Programme later on. However, as far as possible, the improvements provided under the Interim Upgrading Programme for a particular precinct will not be duplicated in the main upgrading package for that precinct. The full interim upgrading cost expended by Government on the precinct will also be deducted from the precinct's main upgrading budget. For example, the total direct upgrading cost for a 3-room flat under the Basic Package of the Main Upgrading Programme is about $22,500. If the flat has enjoyed $6,000 worth of

Column: 364

interim upgrading works, it is only eligible for $16,500 worth of improvement works under the Main Upgrading Programme later on.

    In other words, the total upgrading budget for a precinct is fixed. The Interim Upgrading Programme enables the Town Council to implement part of the upgrading works earlier leaving the major component, involving mainly works within the flat, to be done later under the Main Upgrading Programme.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, I think many Members like me are unaware that there are the Interim and Major Upgrading Programmes. Can the Minister explain the differences of these two programmes?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, maybe the Member for Potong Pasir was too deeply involved with other matters. This was announced in the press.

    The Interim Upgrading Programme, as I explained, covers a budget of about $6,000 per unit and is intended to allow the Town Council to undertake works primarily in the precinct and outside the flat within the block, things like addition of linkways, reconstruction of recreational facilities, repainting of the block, lift landings on every floor, if it is possible and if it is within budget, ie, items under the Main Upgrading Programme which can be done earlier and which will not be duplicated later.

EXPIRED CERTIFICATES OF ENTITLEMENT
(Recycling)


    8. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Communications if he will "recycle" Certificates of Entitlement which have expired.

     The Minister of State for Communications (Cdre Teo Chee Hean) (for the Minister of State for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, under the Vehicle Quota System, expired Certificates of Entitlement (COE) are recycled back into the quota. However, with effect from 29th January 1994, instead of being recycled into the same vehicle category, expired

Column: 365

Certificates of Entitlement will be set aside for redistribution amongst all vehicle categories in the following quota year.

    COEs tendered out each month represent available road space to accommodate additional vehicles on the roads. Expired COEs represent unallocated road space which if not taken up by one particular vehicle category should fairly go to other roadusers.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sir, will the Minister of State confirm that COEs which have been tendered for by motor cycle dealers but are not used will now be recycled and these can be converted for other vehicle COEs?

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, that is correct.

TAXI FARES
(Increase)


    9. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Communications whether taxi fares will be increased in view of the escalation of tender prices of Certificates of Entitlement.

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, applications for taxi fare revisions are considered by the Public Transport Council (PTC). If the taxi operators wish to raise fares, they have to apply to the Council. The operators will have to satisfy the Council that the proposed fare increase is justified.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, has the increase in COE prices eaten into the income of taxi drivers?

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, this information is available to the taxi operators/companies and perhaps the Member would want to direct his question there.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I am sure the Minister has such data from the Public Transport Council. Unless, of course, he does not have it, then I will let it rest.

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Sir, the information is available to the Public Transport Council. I do not have it with me today.

Column: 366

But this is data which the Public Transport Council will take into account together with data concerning other issues which are relevant to the area of taxi fares before it decides on whether taxi fares ought to be adjusted.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, if the increase in COE prices has affected the income of taxi drivers, would there not be some adjustments in taxi fares?

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, perhaps it is useful here to reiterate the principles on which taxi fares are based. The Member has chosen to single out one particular aspect. But the Public Transport Council has to consider all aspects, from the taxi users' point of view and from the taxi companies' point of view. These factors include the cost of owning and operating taxis, the earnings and patronage of taxis and the profitability of taxi companies. Apart from these factors, the PTC also considers the overall principle on which taxi fares are based, that there must be a parity of statutory cost between taxis and cars so that our available road space is used more efficiently. So this is the totality of factors which the Public Transport Council has to consider and not just the particular factor which the Member has raised.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: If we take the question of totality of taxis as against private motor cars, when the maximum number of taxis is reached, the Ministry could easily curtail them. But that is not the position today. As long as the taxi companies can afford the taxis, they will be allowed to buy taxis. Is that not right? I think the question of supply of taxis is really not an issue.

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Sir, I do not understand his question.

     Mr Speaker: I do not understand the Member too. Mr Chiam, could you ask your supplementary question?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Yes, I am asking a supplementary question just to follow up on what the Minister has informed this House. He said one of the questions is the totality of the supply of taxis on the roads. My question is: at the moment, if at any

Column: 367

time the taxis reach the maximum number, the Government could easily freeze the number of taxis. But that is not the case. Is there not a justification for adjustments in taxi fares?

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Sir, I do not follow the logic of the Member's point. I am not sure whether he is suggesting that we freeze the number of taxis as a solution. If that is the case, I do not think that is a good solution at all.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: There was a recent report that the taxi association, because of the rise in COE prices, made representations to increase the taxi fare slightly. The Minister gave the answer that one has to look at the totality of the problem. One of the problems is the supply of taxis on the roads. I believe that is what the Minister said. But that certainly is not an issue at the moment, is it not? Because the supply of taxis has not reached such a stage where you could curb taxis. So taxi companies are still allowed to increase their fleet as long as they can pay for the COE. In other words, as long as they pay for the higher price of taxis which is to be paid by taxi drivers ---

     Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Chiam, could you ask your question?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: The Minister says he does not understand my question. I have to explain.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Chiam, could you get to the point and ask your supplementary question? If you have no further points, please resume your seat.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: My question is the supply of taxis is not an issue, is it not?

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Sir, the supply of taxis is not an issue.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck (Nominated Member): Sir, having heard so much, can the Minister tell us whether taxi fares should be increased in the near future?

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, that is a matter for the Public Transport

Column: 368

Council to decide. The Public Transport Council will consider it when the taxi companies make an application.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: Sir, as far as the Minister is concerned, there will be no taxi fare increases.

     An hon. Member: He did not say that.

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, I said the Public Transport Council will consider this if and when the taxi companies make a proposal.

BUSINESSES WITHIN RESTRICTED ZONE
